newsitem.title: USA: Congress passes disaster aid, sends to White House.
newsitem.headline: Congress passes disaster aid, sends to White House.

text.p: Congress Thursday passed a compromise bill to fund disaster aid and U.S. military operations abroad after Republican leaders cleared it of provisions unacceptable to President Clinton.

Voting simultaneously, the bill cleared the Senate 78-21 and the House 348 to 74. It provides $5.6 billion for North and South Dakota and Minnesota, the states hit hardest by spring floods, and 32 other states that suffered from winter storms, tornados and natural disasters.
The disaster relief legislation now goes to the White House where the president is expected to sign it into law.
It also provides $1.9 billion to pay for U.S. military operations in Bosnia and the Gulf. The remainder will pay for non-emergency programs.

As part of the compromise, Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, won the right to bring up at a later date legislation to continue federal funding beyond the Oct. 1 start of the new 1998 fiscal year.

Republicans also settled for a report from the Commerce Department on its plans for counting the population in 2000 and dropped the ban on the use of sampling surveys to estimate the population. A provision to ease granting of rights-of-way for construction of roads on federal lands was dropped.
